greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of permutations of {1,2,...,n} having no increasing odd cycles. A cycle (b(1), b(2), ...) is said to be increasing if, when written with its smallest element in the first position, it satisfies b(1)<b(2)<b(3)<... .  A cycle is said to be odd if it has an odd number of entries.
formula: a(n) ~ exp(-sinh(1)) * n! = 0.308756853522... * n!. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 16 2014
example: a(4)=9 because we have (12)(34), (13)(24), (14)(23), and the six cyclic permutations of {1,2,3,4}.
maple: g := exp(-sinh(z))/(1-z): gser := series(g, z = 0, 27): seq(factorial(n)*coeff(gser, z, n), n = 0 .. 23);
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 27 2011
